body:
sounds like a good first issue?
"implementing estimator" guide here: https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/developer_guide/add_estimators.html
Should we also add a parameter "round to next multiple of", or a parameter that contains a finite set of values to round to?
Might also be worth allowing to encode intervals somehow, e.g., round to the next points contained in a `pd.IntervalIndex`

Hi @fkiraly i'd like to pick this up please - it looks like it would be just implementing the `BaseTransformer._fit()` method?
My suggested implementation is
- `BaseTransformer`  child class
- _fit() method to round to integers (initial requirement for discrete values) as default.
- Constructor /`__init__` taking optional arguments : 
  - Round to dp `round_to_dp:Optional[int]=None`
  - Round to multiple of: `round_to_multiple:Optional[Union[float,int]]=None` 
  - List of finite values to round to `round_to_list:Optional[Union[float,int]]=None`
 
I am a little confused by the `pd.IntervalIndex` but we can clear that up later 👍

@AJarman, sure!

I'm not sure though why you want to implement the `_fit` method. Should the rounding not happen in the `_transform` method? There's nothing to fit as far as I can see.

Probably just a typo of yours? Otherwise your explanation looks good.

Re `pd.IntervalIndex`, just ignore that fo the start (sorry for being confusing).

Hello,
Yes I have started the implementation, I meant `_transform` of course 😄  that was a strange typo.

I am assuming that we don't want to store the old (untransformed/rounded) values and return them in `_inverse_transform`?
My understanding is that this would be the last step in a `TransformedTargetForecaster` pipeline and therefore the only method used is actually `_transform()`?

> I am assuming that we don't want to store the old (untransformed/rounded) values and return them in `_inverse_transform`?

That wouldn't work, since in general we'd be seeing new indices.

What I'd do is to have `inverse_transform` just to return `X`, since the rounded value itself is in a sense the "best guess" at what it was rounded from

> My understanding is that this would be the last step in a `TransformedTargetForecaster` pipeline and therefore the only method used is actually `_transform()`?

Yes, that is the usage intended by @aiwalter and probably typical usage, although we shouldn't rule out that users may want to use it elsewhere.

issue.title: [ENH] Rounding forecasts / Discretizer

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:

Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [DOC] or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, documentation or bug

##### For new estimators
- [x] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
> What I'd do is to have inverse_transform just to return X, since the rounded value itself is in a sense the "best guess" at what it was rounded from

For this case, we have the tag `"skip-inverse-transform": True`, so no `inverse_transform` should be implemented. The method `inverse_transform` should only be implemented if its actually possible to inverse the transformation. As this is not the case here, we can leave it empty as e.g. also for `Imputer`
but isn´t the identity an "approximate inverse" here?
As a user, I expect from `inverse_transform` not an approximation

Sorry I have been slow with this, unfortunately work has been busy.
Hopefully I can pick this up again soon. 
I am interesting in completing the holidays transformer as well.
@AJarman, great to hear back from you! Looking forward to the PR.
